column1: Description	Commenting	Ogling/Facial Expressions/Staring	Touching /Groping
0000	n the eyes of many
column2: the offices of Pakistan are filled with lecherous bosses. All too often
column3: working women have tales of their perversions the lesser ones include gaze and glance
column4: the occasional grope
column5: the unwanted text message
column6: the innuendo the bigger ones include invitations to meet outside the office
column7: over lunch or dinner  with plum assignments
column8: promotions
column9: job security and professional reputations hanging in the balance.Resignation is no guarantee of reprieve there are reference letters to be obtained
column10: future employment to be worried about. In an expensive
column11: inflationwracked and increasingly competitive Pakistani workplace
column12: there are many women who continue to be targets for men with power.The arithmetic of want and need is in display divorced women
column14: the older and the unmarried are particularly vulnerable to harassment. In the words of one single mother who endured 10 years of harassment
column16: and any attempt to escape is punished further with denials of promotions and humiliation before colleagues. Coworkers
column19: eager to avoid a situation that could result in retaliation
column20: a loss of their own positions. Sexual harassment from superiors is hence often coupled with isolation by colleagues who watch
column21: witness and withdraw. The harassed are not only the persecuted but also the pariah.There is a law against all this in Pakistan. The Protection Against Harassment of Women at the Workplace Act 2010
column22: which will be six years old
column23: is a thorough document. The code of conduct included in it defines harassment as any unwelcome sexual advance
column24: request for sexual favours or other verbal or written communication or physical conduct of a sexual nature
column26: causing interference with work performance or creating an intimidating
column28: or the attempt to punish the complainant for refusal to comply with such a request or is made a condition for employment.It goes on to add that the above is unacceptable behaviour in the organisation and at the workplace
column29: including in any interaction or situation that is linked to official work or official activity outside the office.The abuse of authority
column31: and retaliation are the three categories that mandate action against a harasser. Detailed stipulations are set out for the establishment of investigative committees
column34: who are charged with resolving the issues raised. A range of penalties from censure to outright dismissal are postulated. All employers are required to display the code of conduct prominently on their premises.When the law was passed in 2010
column35: it was feted as a success. It would take time for its provisions to change the culture of the workplace
column36: the more circumspect said. Change comes slowly but a law is a first step a legislative commitment supported by elected representatives signals that the path ahead will be a different one
column37: in this case one where the harassment of women in the workplace would not be permitted.Not much has happened since then. Harassment is still rampant in the workplace (the majority of workplaces have little idea as to what the code of conduct is
column38: let alone of the requirement to display it visibly in employee areas).Women still regularly report being verbally harassed and even physically assaulted by their superiors who
column39: making calculations regarding their need for a job
column42: unabashedly continue with such acts. In the face of unwanted advances
column43: Pakistans women continue to find themselves alone
column44: unsure of where to take their complaints and how to protect themselves.Even in the development sector
column45: where the very agenda of many organisations is to empower women
column47: a cofounder of an organisation faced so much harassment by a male colleague that she was ultimately forced out. New
column48: more pliant women hired to take her position have since complained of similar problems. The man in question
column51: undoubtedly displaying similarly harassing behaviour to new prey. Other men have come to his defence  perhaps recognising their own behaviour in those of others and eager to ensure that no one gets punished.Misogyny is manufactured in two major flavours in Pakistan. The first is on the premises of religious obscurantists whose hankering for the reinstatement of a strictly segregated society sees the harassmentfilled workplace as a grim substantiation of their warnings. Women should not be in the workplace at all
column52: the male conscience is unable to police itself.The second
column53: one that wrongly labels itself as liberal and progressive
column54: imagines it to mean a licence to harass and harangue. A womans willingness to put up and shut up is
column57: its illogical mindset equating women in the public sphere with women sexually available to all men who may want them. The two flavours compete
column58: their poisons infecting the working lives of women  doctors
column63: professors and countless others  who are daily forcefed these bitter morsels of misogyny.Laws alone cannot change society the sexual harassment of women (and nearly everyone who reads this article either knows someone or is someone who has faced harassment) continues because it is considered permissible
column64: something women ask for when they leave their homes.This belief is reflected all the time and everywhere in Pakistan
column65: in soap operas that vilify working women as predators out to seduce innocent men
column66: to workplace conversations in which men dissect the desirability of their female colleagues
column67: their participation often a measure of a masculinity that fears competition from women. In the matter of sexual harassment in Pakistans workplaces
column68: there are the guilty and the very guilty
column69: they are far too many men complicit
column71: eager to embrace or enforce their right to harass.	0	0	1

column1: 0001	Four or five recent events of violence and abuse
column2: and the public reaction to them
column3: merit comment. First
column4: it is amazing how distinctions are being drawn by many between language used inside the parliament and outside. Let me begin with unreservedly condemning Defence minister
column5: Khwaja Asifs
column6: comment on opposition leader Shireen Mazaris voice his rhetorical request to make her voice feminine and the use of the term truck trolley.Mohammed Hanifs insightful piece on the subject correctly identifies these remarks as harking to patriarchal expectations of how everything woman should conform to a standard set by a male how men in this society feel  to dictate terms
column7: behaviour
column8: dress and even tenor of voice to a woman. From anyone else it would have been bad enough
column9: but from a member of parliament and a cabinet minister
column10: everyone expects a higher standard of restraint and control over his anger.However
column11: the seriousness with which this is being debated and protested in the parliament makes me a little perplexed. When the same parliamentarians indulge in
column13: much worse language and behaviour outside the parliament in public spaces
column14: on national television and social media
column15: how do they expect to have it not creep into the house? Arent they the same people
column16: talking about each other outside and inside the house? Indeed
column17: arent their supporters and we all a part of the same society? I was dismayed
column18: but not too surprised by the altercation in the house between Ms Mazari and Khwaja Asif.I am more surprised at the indignation
column19: given that the indignant people know very well how low the standards of any kind of discourse have plunged all around us.The same PTI
column20: that is up in arms right now (rightly)
column21: has never bothered to condemn or be indignant about the utterly obscene abuse hurled at their sisters and fellow citizens who oppose them politically. One is witness to such language
column22: abuse and misogyny on social media and television day in and day out. PTI leaders language and abuse for their male opponents from atop containers and on television shows is no secret either
column23: hence I do not feel the need to repeat it here.Other parties
column25: have been guilty of similar behaviour
column26: though not to the same cesspit extent. But they certainly are guilty of acting surprised when something like this happens on the floor of the house. They should have been condemning and boycotting those who have played an active part in dragging standards of discourse so low that one is afraid to even speak for fear of abuse.One of the guilty parties is certainly the media. Everyone knows which channels or show hosts love to create situations that might give dividends in the shape of some abuse
column29: punches or glasses of water and coffee thrown about. Why then do those who claim to be above it all not boycott these channels and shows? Why does every MNA
column33: economist etc.still behave like a media whore and grace shows of hosts they know encourage abuse
column34: fights and bad language to obtain ratings? Why do they act all sanctimonious now?It is appalling that leading lights of several opposition parties continued to spend all their energies and time
column35: and use up all of the medias energy and time on the so called TORs for the Panama Leaks commission day in and day out. It seemed as if nothing else was happening in the country as if everyday there was not a report of a woman being burnt alive for honour
column36: or some other equally horrifying or serious issue that could merit their attention. But the self serving focus on going after the Prime Minister to the exclusion of all other duties was disgusting to say the least.Ones ears oozed with pus at the nonstop months long hyena shrieking press conferences and appearances on TV shows on the Panama TORs. It was only when the fourth girl in four days was murdered that leader of the Senate
column38: took notice and tasked the senate to do something about it  after which everyone made it their cause. This is the level of apathy towards the plight of the people generally
column39: and to the growing violence towards women.Is our rulers apathy
column40: and the resultant impunity from violence against women
column41: exactly not the reason that Senator Hamdullah (I cant believe he is a senator) of the JUI thought he could
column42: in the presence of several people in the studio
column44: level not only the most explicit
column45: pornographic and filthy abuse at well known rights defender and columnist Marvi Sirmed
column46: but also thought he could beat her up? What he did
column48: in public should demonstrate to everyone the level of apathy towards violence against women in this country it should demonstrate to everyone what is going on behind closed doors. If this man thought he could
column50: get away with what he was doing
column51: it should tell all something about the state of this society.So fearless is the JUI
column52: and sure of support from the ruling party and the government of the day
column53: that after the day befores assault on Marvi Sirmed
column54: Hafiz Uzaifa Shakir of JUIF yesterday released a video saying
column55: hum Pashtun gali ka jawab goli se dete hein (we Pashtun respond to abuse with bullets).It is tragic and heartbreaking that not a single PMLN leader has publicly condemned the JUI senator for reasons of political expediency. It is brave women like Marvi Sirmed who stand to support elected governments it is people like her who stand to protect the democratic project but the democrats we support and protect forsake us at these crunch times that are true tests of democratic norms and values.	1	0	0

column1: 0002	This article was written last year when this situation took place. I was barely entering 11th grade. Now
column2: as I leave high school with flashbacks of this day and all the times my body has been the empty canvas for boys to splatter paint on
column3: I will tell you the story of a 10th grader in Gurgaon.quotThe strangers lips grazed upon the ends of my cheek. My bruised arm was pinned down on the dusty grey ground of the room while I kept my alert eyes outside on the faces of unknown men in uniform. They smirked as the stranger slid his snakelike fingers down my body. He struggled to undo the button. I could feel my eyes turn red when I bit him hard into his shoulder and in a small voice said
column4: No
column5: I have to leave. I dont like this. I felt the empty liquor bottle against my legs and his hands against my flesh. I jerked up and pushed him aside. My head buzzed of alcohol and panic as I managed to stand up and look around. Did I really want this? He straightened up and pressed my frail body upon the naked wall. No
column6: I did not. I pushed him aside and ran towards the open hall. Men of all ages stood on the railings
column7: oblivious of the act. My cheeks burned of forced kisses and shame. Holding my shoes in my hands
column8: I scurried through the staircase in the search of a known face. Who was I looking for? Who was I running from? I reached the cold lobby of an office. I stared at the entrance
column9: and there he was my strange glaring at my anxious face. He shoved my stiff self on the closed elevator
column10: seeking to unfasten my pair of shorts. He settled for forcing his slithering fingers down my waist. He whispered
column11: I am going to finger you like an asshole
column12: as I whimpered and hopped away from him. I felt the back of my clothes
column13: seeking for a phone. It wasnt there. A rush of panic and exhaustion
column14: and I fled out of the office to the hallway. I rummaged around the building
column15: exploring every step I took earlier
column16: to search for a prized possession. It was not there. My eyes burned even more now. Tears blinded my vision and settled on my raw cheeks. He was behind me. I rushed downstairs and headed for the busy road. It was broad daylight
column17: as I scuttled barefoot in the search of my friend. It was too late. She was gone
column18: and my stranger was behind me
column19: grabbing my shirt. His strong hands ripped the cloth. My bare back became exposed to the blinking lights and stare of million nameless men. I cried for help but nobody cared enough to hear. I ran faster
column20: without the possession of a phone
column21: money or my bag. Why was I here? I gazed at the crowd nearby. I came to rest on a staircase. Tears ran down my face
column22: unknown figures settled around me but in my head
column23: I knew what to do. Him
column24: I whispered as I strived to punch the familiar number down on a phone.Do you remember the moment when you were child and you had gone astray from your parents in a crammed up market place? How at that moment
column25: you were devoid of any thoughts and the only thought of worth was how to get back to your safe haven? Do you remember the worry on their faces? That moment was of such magnitude. I shook back and forth
column27: unable to see his delicate features muddled up with concern. Men and women walked past me
column28: putting forward a helping hand but I did not trust them. It was a matter of minutes
column29: when his agonized face rushed past me. I stood up and ran towards his open arms. The world stood still as he held me. I took in the accustomed smell of his cologne and felt a homesick wave crash on the walls of my head. Im scared
column30: hes going to find me. I said
column31: and that was enough for him to know. He took out a grey shirt from his bag and walked me out of the eyesight of alien people. Wear it
column32: he murmured and propped his hand on my shoulders to pull me close. He rescued my other friend from the clutches of my stranger and his friends and departed from the cursed location. The ride ended at my house. He held my face and in a low voice
column33: inaudible to my friend in the next room
column34: asked me for a favour. Dont do anything stupid
column36: as if reading my mind. The state of my friend was beyond the category of wasted
column38: he picked her up from the marble floor and led her towards the societys gates. He waved a brief goodbye and timidly walked away from me.Sometimes
column39: you dont need words to explain how you feel. Sometimes
column42: enfolded in his scent from his shirt
column43: I felt possible. I was petrified from the episode
column44: but his face made it easier to breathe in. Sometimes
column45: you dont need to be dating or loving somebody for months to feel comfortable with. You dont need to kiss him
column46: or even have him around you all the time. Just his nervous presence lingering around you in that moment is enough to demonstrate and establish a brief connection. He was my safe haven
column47: even if for those few minutes. I was sorry that it was over but all the more glad
column48: he was there for me. When he said those words on the phone
column49: they were a formality. But standing there in the park
column50: watching him walk towards the gates
column51: I could feel it happening. It may not have been an episode of such importance for him
column53: it changed everything.Im sorry that the dance ended
column56: I swear the world stood impossibly still.quotI attempted suicide a few hours later
column57: but I was saved. And I live to be strong

column1: 0003	Harassment is a blow any girl can suffer anywhere. Harassment is not necessarily an attack by just strangers
column2: it can be an intense assault within the confinements of your house you considered your home. Here I am typing my own story of an account which shook my life and left it scarred in a way that I attest as irreversible. On an eventful Sunday
column3: I returned home to an eerie silence. The tension in the air was palpable and the looks in the eyes of my dad were unmistakably of anger. I kept quiet and walked to my room
column4: hoping that I was just worrying for no reason. I slouched on my bed with a slice of chocolate cake and tuned into my favorite channel on TV. Two hours later I was summoned by my Dad for a discussion and I knew at that very moment that all my fears will materialize in a span of few seconds. I come from a conservative family
column5: where I am the only girl who is working in a corporate
column6: who is career oriented
column7: and independent in her thoughts and actions. Truly liberal and yet righteous in my thoughts
column8: I have never questioned my approach towards life. I have been constantly put down by my family
column9: I have incessantly been compared to my elder brother
column10: my thoughts have been suppressed
column11: and my ideals have been questioned. That night
column12: my dad was furious for I was out on a Sunday with my friends for a social cause
column13: in a mixed group of girls and guys
column14: which was unacceptable to him though God knows why he coeducated me though God knows why despite being an educated man
column15: his thoughts were shallow and hurtful as they demeaned women. He was in a rage that I was too independent for his governance and societal norms. He considered my independence and will to make a mark as insolence and immoral. He wanted me to be confined to the four walls of my house
column16: preparing myself to get married without even realizing my dreams. As I sat there objecting
column17: he asked for my phone and decided to cut me off from my social circle. He crushed my brand new phone to pieces and threw the broken pieces right at my face
column18: the shattered screen leaving scratches wherever the tiny broken glasses pricked me. As I further relented
column19: he hurled abuses and called me names a father can never associate with his own daughter. My tears had dried listening to it all
column20: I was feeling stronger and motivated to not succumb to this harassment this was the worst I had seen and somewhere it brought me to peace that I had already faced the worst. I constantly defended my education
column22: and my strong ideals against his baseless
column24: and barbaric thoughts. I would call it barbaric as I could have never imagined that my own father would move agitatedly around looking for a knife in the kitchen to further harm me. That just killed every emotion I could associate with a fatherdaughter relationship. I stood upto him and looked him in the eye and told him that this was the worst thing he could ever do and he shall never be forgiven. Our relationship ended that night and I havent spoken to him eversince. As I walked out of that room
column26: just for the sake of my mother
column27: I wept endlessly in my room
column28: not able to fathom what just happened to me and why. My dads extreme behavior
column30: and the fear in my brothers eyes made me realize how shallow our society is how can we even call it a society where ones life means nothing just because she is a girl. Who allows them to believe that women are weak or inferior?  There is absolutely no logic
column32: and absolutely no forgiveness for anyone who cannot respect a woman
column33: be it our own parents. I know of so many girls who are living a far more dreadful existence and I have penned my story not for sympathy
column34: not for appreciation for standing up for myself
column35: but simply to encourage all the women and men reading this to propagate an understanding of how beautiful
column37: and amazing women are as gods creation. I want us all to make a society where every woman is safe
column39: and successful where every woman is an equal to every man. Do not cry
column41: and do not deprive yourself of education as that is your true independence and absolute achievement. As we pin the creeps across the cities
column42: and enlist all the crime spots around us
column43: we need to realize that women are suffering at the hands of their own families. A true movement of women safety will begin when all the women stand up for themselves. Only when you respect yourself will the world respect you. Stay strong

column1: 0004	It was my first day in Bangalore(after spending 4 years in Delhi). My kitchen was not yet set up hence we(me and my male friend) went out for dinner to a restaurant which was located at a very central area. At about 1030PM
column2: we were done with our dinner and while heading towards my car which was parked about 500 meters from the restaurant
column3: four men(looked like in their forties) started calling me out
column4: saying 'excuse me'
column5: on turning towards them
column6: they started teasing me
column7: passing comments like 'miss you'
column8: 'hello' and all. My friend got furious with them but I somehow managed to convince him to get into the car and  We chose not to react. However
column9: my friend asked me to stay inside the car and went out to note down their car number. These men seemed to notice him note down their car number
column10: and after a while
column11: they started man handling him. Fortunately I had a 'Naga chilly spray' with me. I took that out
column12: ran towards them and managed to knock out three of them with the same. The fourth man got hold of my hand and pushed me down the road
column13: and I hit my head. The saddest part was that people around were watching as if there is a drama being played on the road. Nobody came for help. While my friend was busy at the other end trying to fight with the rest of them
column14: I saw one of the men take out iron rods from their car dickey. I pulled my friend telling him no one is gonna come for help and we will not be able to help ourselves either. We ran towards the car and immediately went inside. On turning the car to take a Uturn
column15: two or three of them came running towards us with the intention to hit us
column16: but since we were already inside
column17: they smashed all sides of my car glasses. We rushed to the nearest police station asking for help. On showing them their car number(which my friend luckily noted down)
column18: the police personnel hesitated to file an FIR(As per our understanding
column19: they seemed to be local/political goons residing in the same area. We left my car at the police station for the night
column20: returned home at about 3AM in the morning and again went back to the police station for filing the FIR. After repeated failed request
column21: we had to use my friend's position(he is in the army)
column22: we spoke to the head of that police station and filed the FIR. I was totally devastated from inside and wanted to leave Bangalore the very day. I cried the whole night and asked my friend to drop me home
column26: but I woke up the next day
column27: and decided to fight this out. Being a woman living alone in the city
column28: with 'different' looks and a car that these people can easily identify
column29: I didn't want to get into the mess of making rounds at the police station
column30: and court case(my friend also had to leave for work in few days)
column31: I decided to take back the FIR but also stay back in Bangalore and move on. We looked for a new house the very same day and I moved to a farther and safer house. It may be a question on someone's head as to why I withdrew the FIR and didn't try to punish those culprits. But we all know that the country that we live in. Even murderers are set free from punishment
column32: leave aside eve teasers and people who made injury to us physically and damaged our property. This is a story
column33: not only because I want to share one
column34: but it shows how our own country has failed to protect its own citizens
column35: a story of the faith that a woman doesn't have in her country's governing authority
column36: a story that shows how we humans lag in being a helping hand when others are in need(yes
column37: there were families watching the incident)
column39: that no matter how much hatred the world puts into you
column40: you still need to have a love for humanity
column42: hoping that we(women) shall overcome from all these pain one day.....	0	0	0

column1: 0005	The following is what i had written a day after this horrific experience 23 years back.quotTeri chut lene me maza aa jaegaquot he said to me. Maybe it is my fault. I never should have known what that means. And I replied with quotmar ja jakequot
column2: my voice quivering. And as with every sharp exchange of words
column3: later
column4: for quite some time I thought of better responses I could've given. quotPolice ke pass chalega? mujhe bhi maza aa jaega..quot or quotquot well thoughts I am still not able to put into words. Suddenly I was given a glimpse of what it would feel like to be a rape victim. It probably would be too clichd to say that I suddenly felt exposed to everyone around me. At the same I could see indifference in many eyes around me. They knew not what had just happened in the middle of the road
column5: in broad daylight (please note that I am still speaking like a rape victim). I saw a mother with a daughter probably 810 years old with her. The gap of about 1m between them made me feel insecure for them. I wanted to shout out to the mother to grasp her daughter's hand and hold her close. And I suddenly understood why mothers are so protective. I knew he was still somewhere around me. Watching. Loving and getting high on the reaction he'd caused in me. This thought made me lighten up. I didnt want to give him the satisfaction. I looked around cheerily again. Well not really
column6: just normal enough. All the men around me suddenly seemed to be leering. A casual glance felt like a perverted gaze. I wished my pickup to be here already. The stupid 20 something year olds that I have encountered innumerous times suddenly began to seem threatening. Who am I to judge? I know sex addicts. I have 1st hand experience with them and their lust and what their addiction does to people around them. Suddenly a thought comes to me. He had guts. I mean at this stage in his addiction (Im assuming that I am not blunderously attractive and he just says this kind of thing to young girls)
column7: he probably does it out of compulsion
column8: but he must have started somewhere. I dont know a single person who would say out loud something like this
column9: even in a relationship
column10: during a naughty role play night. This I believe is tougher than proposing to a girl. Or maybe it isnt for him. Maybe he was brought up in a family in which an angry father told his daughter off with heavy abuses
column11: the mother was openly told by the father that she is to pleasure him tonight
column12: the siblings would call each other swear words involving their mother
column13: the sister was casually called prostitute and told to do things wives are fit for.PS Please note that the date n time are approximates.	1	0	0

column1: 0006	I think there is no woman who has not gone through some form of sexual harassment in this country. It is sad that I cant step outside my home without a hint of fear in my mind. I have had experiences standing at my bus stop as a child
column2: with a friend of mine waiting for my school bus to come
column3: when a man in a big car took rounds throwing pieces of paper with his number written on it. Then there was another time when I was standing outside my house waiting for a friend to come pick me up when a car stopped and refused to leave until he saw my friend come. For God's sake right outside my house?!? I would like to state another example when me and my friend were returning from the market in a rickshaw and we were followed by a car full of men passing lewd comments and the rickshaw guy had the sense of taking a different route. When he dropped us home he asked us quotDidi kya aap un logo ko jaanti thiquot? and i replied saying no
column4: and his answer was quotisliye maine doosra raasta le liyaquot. What i'm trying to say here is that it is not just the poor and uneducated people to blame every single time
column5: there are quoteducated menquot from well to do families in big cars doing this!!! Another time i was stopped by a well spoken man on the defence colony  kotla road again in a big car asking if i want to be friends and whether he can drop me home
column6: when i said no he kept following me
column7: i had to go to a crowded place in my market in the colony to get away from him. Another thing i would like to say is that the I am a resident of Defence Colony which is quotsupposedlyquot a colony for the defence people
column8: should be safe but sadly it isn't. Nearly every evening i notice prostitutes standing in nooks and corners amp cars stopping and picking them up inside the colony itself. There are a number of lady boys who stand right at road that turns into Defence Colony opposite the Lajpat Nagar metro station. At the turn there is a police check post at night for so called quotsecurity reasonsquot and they stop cars as and when they want (only when they're bored or want to make some money). Do they not know that these lady boys/prostitutes stand there and get picked up every night??? What is the police doing??? It happens right under their noses and they're oblivious to it!!! This is a great initiative but i hope it continues and is not short lived. We really need to do something to bring about a change in the mindset of people in this country which ironically worships goddesses !!	1	1	0

column1: 0008	I was walking down the 15th  main and just turned into the 16th cross in HSR layout sector 4 when I heard the sound of a scooter behind me.  So I moved to the left hand side of the road.  That particularly short stretch is a little dark as there are no houses on either side of the road and the trees are tall and thickly grown hiding the light from the street lamp.
